It may be used freely by individuals for research, teaching, and personal use as long as this statement of availability is included in the text. For all other use contact the Tennessee State Library and Archives, 403 Seventh Avenue North, Nashville, TN 37243-0312. (615) 741-2764.

bibl.title: [Entries from the Cherokee Supreme Court Docket, 1823-1834, New Echota] 1830 Oct. 23
bibl.note: This is an excerpt from the Cherokee Supreme Court docket for the years 1823 to 1834. The Cherokee Supreme Court convened annually in New Echota beginning on the second Monday in October and lasting three weeks. This excerpt is from the Saturday October 23, 1830 session of court, during which a series of civil cases were heard. Entries from this Supreme Court docket cover items ch100-ch163.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 2.1 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

div.head: October Term 1830
Saturday 23rd
div.p: Court met according to ajournment adjournment Present their honours honors , Walter S. Adair Andrew Ross & John Huss Judges

George Harlin by his agent Eli Harlin
vs.
Michael Huffacre

Debt on a/c. Execution issued
Jan January 8th 1831
the Court find for the plaintiff four hundred and twenty six dollars and thirty one and a fourth cents.

William Post
vs.
Samul Samuel Mays

the court decide that the corner starting from a pine tree on the hill, and running a strait straight
line direction to the mouth of the hallow, near the corner of Posts field, deviding bettween dividing between the parties, shall be the true line, and that the National Marshal as soon as conveniant convenient proceed to the place notifying the parties & mark the line.
This case was brought up from the circuit court on a point of law, and it is decided that the case be taken up in the circuit court for trial.
The court give Judgement in favour favor of the plaintiff for eighty five dollars and seventy five cents, with lawful interest from the fifteenth of Decr. December 1829.

I do hereby acknowledge myself as scarcity to stay the above judgement for six months according to law.
Samuel Mays

Robt. Robert Paris
vs
John Gillen and Giles McAnulty
The court find for the plaintiff seventy five dollars each-
Court adjourned untill until monday morning 10 oclock Execution issued 9th Decr.
